Central Parkway | city = [[Cincinnati]] | state = [[Ohio]] | country = USA | coordinates = {{Coord|39|6|38|N|84|30|36|W|type:edu_region:US-OH|display=inline,title}} | district = Cincinnati Public Schools | principal = Michael Owens{{cite web|url=http://www.cdab.org/members.asp?SCHOOL_ID=1397 |title=Ohio High School Athletic Association Member Directory |accessdate=March 16, 2010 |publisher=Ohio High School Athletic Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102205537/http://cdab.org/members.asp?SCHOOL_ID=1397 |archivedate=November 2, 2010 }} | schooltype = Public
Magnet school
College-Preparatory
Fine Arts | grades = Kindergarten–12 | age range = 5–17 | campus = Urban | nickname = Raiders{{cite news|title=Surprising SCPA, 13–1, performing on court|first=Shannon|last=Russell|newspaper=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]| date = January 17, 2002 | accessdate = October 6, 2010|url=http://cincinnati.com/preps/2002/01/17/pre_surprising_scpa_13-1.html}} | opened = 1973 | enrollment = 1,300 | enrollment_as_of = 2010 | homepage = [http://scpa.cps-k12.org/ www.scpa.cps-k12.org] }} The '''School for Creative and Performing Arts''' ('''SCPA''') is a [[magnet school|magnet]] arts school in [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], [[United States]], and part of the [[Cincinnati Public Schools]] (CPS). SCPA was founded in 1973 as one of the first magnet schools in Cincinnati and became the first school in the country to combine a full range of arts studies with a complete [[University-preparatory school|college-preparatory]] academic program for elementary through high school students. Of the approximately 350 arts schools in the United States, SCPA is one of the oldest and has been cited as a model for both [[racial integration]] and for arts programs in over 100 cities.{{sfn|Vaccariello|Pyle|1993|p=103|loc="... in the surprisingly well-populated world of art schools (there are over 350 of them) SCPA is one of the oldest and most prestigious"}} SCPA had three different homes in its first four years, including a makeshift campus in the [[Mount Adams, Cincinnati|Mount Adams]] neighborhood and another in [[Roselawn, Cincinnati|Roselawn]]. In 1976, it occupied the Old [[Woodward High School (Cincinnati, Ohio)|Woodward High School]] building, on the site of one of the oldest public schools in the country. The school rose to national prominence in the 1980s, but was nearly closed in the 1990s following a series of scandals, leadership struggles, and an arson fire which destroyed the auditorium. Its reputation recovered in the years that followed and in 2009–10, the school was featured in the [[MTV]] reality series ''[[Taking the Stage]]'', filmed at the school and featuring SCPA students. In 2010 SCPA combined with the Schiel Primary School for Arts Enrichment to create the first [[kindergarten]] through [[twelfth grade]] (about ages five to seventeen) arts school and first private sector/public arts school in the US. A new facility in [[Over-the-Rhine]] was championed by the late [[Cincinnati Pops]] [[Maestro]] [[Erich Kunzel]] and funded through a unique public-private partnership that raised over $31 million in private contributions to match public funding. The building features specialized facilities for the arts and three separate theaters and is the key to redevelopment plans for the area. Students must audition for admission; fewer than 20 percent of those who apply each year are accepted. SCPA is free to CPS students but also attracts tuition-paying students from outside the district and the state. The newly combined school will serve approximately 1,300 students in 2010, offering a curriculum designed to prepare students for professional careers in [[creative writing]], [[dance]], [[drama]], [[music]], [[Stagecraft|technical theater]], and [[visual arts|visual art]]. The emphasis is on performance, and students in every field are required to perform or present their work in public regularly. Students compete successfully in arts competitions locally and internationally. On [[standardized test]]s, SCPA ranks second among Cincinnati public schools. Ninety percent of graduating seniors continue on to college, and those students receive one of the highest levels of scholarship funding in the city. A limited number of extracurricular activities are offered, as students are expected to commit significant after-school time to training and performance. SCPA has produced notable graduates in a wide range of artistic fields, including award-winning actors, singers, directors and technicians. == History == === Background === [[File:Waldrip Dickinson.jpg|thumb|alt=Two men in winter coats and hats standing in crowd in front of tall city buildings |Bill Dickinson (left), who led the school from its founding in 1973 until 1991, and CPS Superintendent Dr. Donald Waldrip at an All-City Boy Choir performance on Cincinnati's [[Fountain Square, Cincinnati|Fountain Square]], c. 1974]] The School for Creative and Performing Arts arose, in part, as a response to the recurring [[desegregation]] battles in the [[Cincinnati Public Schools]] (CPS) in the late 1960s and early 1970s.{{sfn|Waldrip|1976|p=41}} In a 1965 civil rights suit, the city prevailed when a federal judge found that the schools were not intentionally segregated, but that "the racial composition of each school is simply a result of the racial composition of the neighborhoods which they serve".{{cite court |litigants = [[Deal v. Cincinnati Board of Education]] |vol = 244 |reporter = F. Supp. 572 |court = Dist. Court S. D. Ohio | year = 1965 |pinpoint = 580 |url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=1768651766411810675&hl=en&as_sdt=2&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr}} By 1971, Cincinnati's neighborhoods and schools had grown more segregated and the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] upheld [[forced busing]] as a remedy for school segregation in other cities.{{cite court | litigants = Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Bd. of Ed.| vol = 402 | reporter = U.S. 1 | year = 1971 | court = Supreme Court | url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=US&vol=402&invol=1}} Desiring to avoid such drastic remedies for Cincinnati, newly appointed Superintendent Dr. Donald Waldrip pushed forward a program of [[Magnet school|alternative schools]] (later called magnet schools), designed "to calm the desires of parents for academic choice and to stem the demands of federal judges for court-ordered desegregation."{{sfn|Waldrip|1976|p=41}} The theory behind alternative schools was [[school choice|open enrollment]]: students could attend any alternative school they chose at no cost, so long as an even racial balance at the new school was maintained.{{sfn|Griffin|1977|p=87}} So far as possible, students were admitted to these programs on a one white for one black basis.{{sfn|Jacobs & Felix|1977|p=110}} The School for Creative and Performing Arts was the first alternative school in what would become one of the largest and most robust magnet programs in the country.{{sfn|Griffin|1977|p=85}}{{cref |a}} In 1965, Robert McSpadden and Bill Dickinson, both music teachers in the Cincinnati Public Schools, founded the Cincinnati All-City Boy Choir, where they were struck by how the discipline they established for the boys in the choir carried over into their academic studies.{{cite news| last = Stein | first = Jerry| title = The Arts School | newspaper= [[The Cincinnati Post]] | date = November 27, 1976}} They conceived the idea of a school where basic education was combined with intensive attention to children with artistic talents. With the support of Waldrip and Tom Murray, director for the west-central division of Cincinnati elementary schools, they pushed for $119,000 as part of a tax levy referendum in May 1973; the measure was defeated. The school was approved with a drastically reduced budget of $27,000 plus $9,850 from the Board of Education’s general fund. They turned to private funding and won a $292,000 grant from J. Ralph Corbett, one of the city's foremost philanthropists for the arts, and $24,500 for a piano lab from the [[Baldwin Piano Company]], which had manufactured pianos in Cincinnati since 1891.{{cite news| last = Eliot | first = John | title = Mt. Adams School: They're Writing the 'Book' for Alternative Education | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post | date = October 24, 1973}}{{cite book | title = Dwight Hamilton Baldwin (1821–1899) and the Baldwin Piano | last = Wulsin | first = Lucien | location = New York | publisher = Newcomen Society in North America | page = 18 | oclc = 963911 }} The School for Creative and Performing Arts opened in August 1973, as the only [[fourth grade|grade four]] through [[sixth grade|six]] school for the performing arts in the country and the first public school that combined all of the arts in a single program.{{cref |b}} The curriculum included art, [[instrumental]] music, [[choir|choral music]], dance and drama, and was not organized strictly by grade, but permitted students to advance as soon as their abilities allowed.{{cite journal| title = A Fourteen Year Old Dream for the Talented Comes True | journal = Gifted Child Quarterly | volume = 18 | issue = 2 | page = 108 | year = 1974 | issn = 0016-9862 }} Murray explained:
Fourth through sixth grades will be together in classes. Teaching will often be done in teams. Art students will design scenery for plays, written by drama students. Music pupils will supply the music. They work together regardless of age. In reading classes they will read according to their own individual levels. A brilliant music student, capable of interpreting Beethoven's wildest dreams, might stumble on fifth level reading. This does not make him a dunce simply a slow reader.{{cite news| title = Alternative School For Arts Opens On Mt. Adams | last = Gardner | first = Jani | newspaper= [[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] | date = August 30, 1973}}
=== Founding in Mount Adams (1973–1975) === [[File:MtAdamsPublicSchool.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A small brick and stone building, seen from the corner view, in front of clear blue sky|Mount Adams Public School, the first home of SCPA. The [[Romanesque Revival]] school house, built by Henry Siter in 1894, was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980.{{cite web|title = Mount Adams Public School | work = National Register of Historic Places | date = November 24, 1980 | publisher = National Park Service | url =http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/ | accessdate = May 19, 2010}} ]]Dickinson was named coordinator and six weeks later he, McSpadden, Murray and others had selected a staff, developed a program, recruited students, and moved into the [[Mount Adams Public School]] building at 1125 St. Gregory Street.{{sfn|Waldrip|1979|p=132}} Described by ''[[Cincinnati Magazine]]'' as "a quaint village of imaginative, arty residents, unusual shops and restaurants, and historic buildings"{{cite news| page = 9 | newspaper = [[Cincinnati Magazine]] | volume = 9 | number = 5 |date = February 1976| title = Queen City History}} and overlooking downtown Cincinnati and the [[Ohio River]], [[Mount Adams, Cincinnati|Mount Adams]] had been home to the [[Art Academy of Cincinnati]] (the museum school of the [[Cincinnati Art Museum]]) since 1887, and was a "mecca for students and teachers of art". The Mount Adams School was nearly defunct, with fewer than 80 students remaining. Fifty of those children, ranging from [[kindergarten]] (around age five) to [[third grade]] (around age eight) remained alongside the new SCPA. A dozen of the Mount Adams [[middle school]] students were accepted into the new program, along with the 140 other fourth through sixth grade pupils selected from schools around the city by audition. By 1974, SCPA had 332 students, with 500 on the waiting list, and had overflowed into rented space in the surrounding neighborhood, including three rooms at the nearby Holy Cross School, two rooms at the community center two blocks away, and large room for drama above Mike's Meat Market across the street. Students practiced instruments in hallways and restrooms, and the library was in the middle of the second floor hall. Student productions were held in other schools around the city, and the first major musical, [[Babes in Toyland (operetta)|''Babes in Toyland'']], was performed at Education Center downtown.{{sfn|Waldrip|1979|p=132}} With plans to expand to [[ninth grade]] (around age 14) and 540 students in 1975, and to [[twelfth grade]] (around age 17) and 1,400 students in 1977, a new facility had to be found. Waldrip proposed the school move to the Old Woodward school building, then home of Abigail Cutter [[Junior High School]], in [[Over-the-Rhine]], a predominantly African-American area near downtown. Neighborhood resistance was strong and opponents, arguing that "the school administration was trying to avoid problems of integration by moving an alternative school to Cutter and transferring Cutter students elsewhere",{{cite news| last = Brookshire | first = Kay | title = Mt. Adams School Bursting at the Seams | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post | date = February 6, 1975}} blocked the plan.{{cite news| title = Planned Growth of Arts School Hinges on Site | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | last = Brookshire | first = Kay | date = April 7, 1975}} Councilwoman Bobbie Stern proposed the school move to [[Cincinnati Museum Center at Union Terminal|Cincinnati Union Terminal]], a [[National Historic Landmark]] which the [[Historic American Buildings Survey]] called "a unique and monumental manifestation of [[Art Deco]] architecture and interior decoration",{{cite book | title = Cincinnati Union Terminal | series = Historic American Buildings Survey (Library of Congress) | publisher = National Park Service | url = http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/hhh.oh0024 | accessdate = May 17, 2010 | pages = 1–2}} noted for its mosaic murals depicting the history of Cincinnati and its [[Rotunda (architecture)|rotunda]], {{convert|106|ft|m}} high and {{convert|110|ft|m}} long, the largest [[semi-dome]] in the western hemisphere.{{cite news| title = The Girls Town Proposal Has Possibilities | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = April 8, 1974}}{{cite web| url = http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1257&ResourceType=Building | title = Cincinnati Union Terminal | date = May 5, 1977 |work=National Historic Landmark summary listing |publisher=National Park Service | accessdate = May 17, 2010}} The facility, vacant since it was abandoned by [[Amtrak]] in 1972, was to house the school, a maintenance facility for the [[Southwest Ohio Regional Transit Authority|Queen City Metro]] transit service, and a new rail terminal for Amtrak. The plan was approved in April 1975 and was due for completion for the 1976 school year.{{cite news| title = Waldrip to Urge Moving Mt. Adams School Next Year | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = May 8, 1975}} === Transition in Roselawn (1975–1976) === Temporary space was needed in the interim, and the school relocated its 550 fourth through ninth grade students to rented space in [[Roselawn, Cincinnati|Roselawn]], the epicenter of Cincinnati's Jewish Community.{{sfn|Fine|Krome|2007|p=8}}{{cite news| last = Brookshire| first = Kay| title = They're Cracking Books at Art School | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post | date = December 5, 1975}} The school was divided between two buildings, the [[Yavneh Day School (Cincinnati, Ohio)|Yavneh Day School]] building at 1636 Summit Road and the nearby Jewish Community Center.{{cite news| title = Rockdale Temple to House School for Creative Arts | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | date = December 20, 1975}} The Yavneh Day school, founded in 1952 by parents who wanted to combine secular and Jewish education for their children, moved to Roselawn in 1958 but had outgrown that facility.{{sfn|Fine|Krome|2007|p=115}} The school had no lockers; students carried their belongings between buildings.{{cref|c}} Lunches were delivered from another school and served at a nearby church. Dickinson became principal in 1975, and worked to fully integrate the arts into the academic program. "Academics don't end when art, drama or music classes begin," he said, "but blend, in an interdisciplinary approach to education." Music study included acoustics and the history and architecture of important musical periods; art history was part of the art curriculum and anatomy and physiology were studied in the dance program. The school was recognized with ''[[The Cincinnati Post]]'s'' Corbett Award in 1976 as "the arts organization making an outstanding contribution to the community". The Union Terminal project was derailed when the three prospective tenants failed to agree on how to share the space. Having outgrown its temporary facilities, SCPA was again forced to find a new home for the following year. After examining options including the historic [[Rockdale Temple]] and two schools slated to be closed in the city's [[West End, Cincinnati|West End]], the school board once again settled on the Old Woodward building, over the objections of the community.{{cite news| title = West End School Closings to be Discussed | last = Brookshire | first = Kay | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | date = November 22, 1975}} === Old Woodward and national attention (1976–1990) === {{See also| Woodward High School (Cincinnati)}} [[File:Old Woodward.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Five story brick and terra cotta building with parking lot and city street in the foreground|The Old Woodward building in 1976. The [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Renaissance Revival]] building is part of the Over-the-Rhine National Register Historic District.]] SCPA's new home was in the heart of [[Pendleton, Cincinnati|Pendleton]] district in Over-the-Rhine. One of the largest German-American neighborhoods in the United States in the 19th century and a famed entertainment district at that time, Over-the-Rhine had declined into an impoverished and crime-ridden enclave for migrant [[Appalachia]]ns in the 20th century.{{sfn|Miller|Tucker|1998|pp=1–3, 75, 78}} By 1970, a combination of [[white flight]] and the destruction of surrounding slums had transformed the area into Cincinnati's most infamous ghetto.{{cite web| title = OTR History | publisher = Over-the-Rhine Foundation | url = http://www.otrfoundation.org/OTR_History.htm| accessdate = May 19, 2010}}{{cite book | pages= 80–81 | title = Revitalizing America's Cities: Neighborhood Reinvestment and Displacement | last1 = Schill | first1= Michael H | last2 = Nathan | first2 = Richard P | last3 = Persaud | first3 = Harrichand | location = Albany | publisher = State University of New York Press | year = 1983 | series = SUNY Series on Urban Public Policy | isbn = 0-87395-742-3 }} It is one of the largest, most intact urban historic districts in the United States and the most dangerous neighborhood in Cincinnati.{{cite web| title = Guide to OTR Architecture | publisher = Over-the-Rhine Foundation | url = http://www.otrfoundation.org/OTR_Architecture.htm | accessdate = May 19, 2010}}{{sfn|Miller|Tucker|1998|p=xix}} The school, with its 650 students, moved into this historic but blighted neighborhood, and its Old Woodward School building at 1310 Sycamore Street. Woodward was one of the oldest public schools in the country, founded as the Woodward Free Grammar School in 1831; it was named for William Woodward, a local tanner who donated the land to provide, in his words, "facilities to educate the children of persons who could not afford the expense of private schooling".{{cite book | title = Old Woodward: A Memorial Relating to Woodward High School, 1831–1836, and Woodward College, 1836–1851, In the City Of Cincinnati| publisher = Old Woodward Club (Press of Robert Clarke & Co.) | year = 1884 | pages = 14, 29 | location = Cincinnati | oclc = 247492599}} The building was replaced once in 1855, and again in 1907 when President [[William Howard Taft]], who graduated from Woodward in 1874, laid the cornerstone of the current building; it opened in 1910.{{cite web|url=http://www.cpsboe.k12.oh.us/general/History/History.html |title=The Early History of Cincinnati Public Schools |publisher=Cincinnati Public Schools |accessdate=November 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080627164917/http://www.cpsboe.k12.oh.us/general/History/History.html |archivedate=June 27, 2008 }} The site is linked to the [[Underground Railroad]], an informal network of secret routes and safe houses used by 19th-century black slaves in the United States; [[Levi Coffin]] (known as "The President of the Underground Railroad") had a home there from 1856 to 1863.{{cite news| last = Mrozowski| first = Jennifer| title = SCPA Boasts History Marker | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer| date = January 6, 2004| url = http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2004/01/06/loc_loc1ascpa.html | accessdate = December 20, 2009}} The five-story brick, stone, and [[terra cotta]] building is approximately {{convert|225000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. Designed by Gustav Brach, it was considered "an architectural gem"{{cite news| last = O'Niell| first = Tom| title = At This Old School Students Must be Creative to Perform | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = November 15, 2002 | url = https://secure.pqarchiver.com/enquirer/access/1835091951.html?FMT=FT&dids=1835091951:1835091951&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+15%2C+2002&author=Tom+O%27Neill&pub=Cincinnati+Enquirer&desc=At+this+old+school%2C+students+must+be | format = fee required | accessdate = December 22, 2009}} in its time, with some of the most modern facilities of its day, including flush toilets, central heating, and two swimming pools.{{cite news| last = Petrie| first = Laurie| title =Current SCPA Location Site of 1831 High School | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post| date = April 20, 1996 | url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72895277.html | format = fee required | accessdate = January 15, 2010}} It is graced with 12 rare [[Rookwood Pottery Company|Rookwood Pottery]] drinking fountains from the early 1900s, gifts of the Art League, founded in 1895, which raised dues from students who would then vote on works of art to buy for the school.{{cite news| title = The Second Coming of the Art League | last = Bloomfield | first = Maureen | newspaper = Cincinnati Magazine |date = July 1997| volume = 30 | number = 10 | page = 25}} The building is part of the Over-the-Rhine [[National Register of Historic Places|National Register Historic District]], which encompasses {{convert | 362.5| acre}} of the original German community and adjoins the [[Sycamore – 13th Street Grouping|Sycamore – 13th Street]] Historic District, which reflects the significant architecture associated with middle and late 19th century [[Greek Revival]], [[Queen Anne Style architecture (United States)|Queen Anne]], and [[Italianate]] styles.{{cite web|title=Over-the-Rhine Historic District |work=National Register Historic Districts in Cincinnati |publisher=City of Cincinnati |url=http://www.cincinnati-oh.gov/cdap/pages/-6758-/ |accessdate=May 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530062032/http://www.cincinnati-oh.gov/cdap/pages/-6758-/ |archivedate=May 30, 2010 }}{{cite web|title=Sycamore-13th Street Grouping Historic District |work=National Register Historic Districts in Cincinnati |publisher=City of Cincinnati |url=http://www.cincinnati-oh.gov/cdap/pages/-9438-/ |accessdate=May 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808142153/http://www.cincinnati-oh.gov/cdap/pages/-9438-/ |archivedate=August 8, 2008 }} [[File:Carousel SCPA Cincinnati 1980.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=black man with sideburns, striped shirt, and plaid pants talks to white girl in calico dress with hat and purse on a stage |''Chicago Hope'' and ''NCIS'' star Rocky Carroll appears in ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]'' in 1980.]] Woodward High School moved to a new facility in [[Bond Hill, Cincinnati|Bond Hill]] in 1953, and the building became Abigail Cutter Junior High School (also known as Cutter), named for William Woodward's wife.{{cite news| title = Historic SCPA Building Soon to be Vacant | last = Fischer | first = Ben | date = April 24, 2010 | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | url = http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20100424/NEWS0102/4250358/Old+SCPA+soon+to+be+empty | accessdate = May 20, 2010}} SCPA occupied the fourth floor in 1976, and the entire building in 1977, displacing the Cutter students to other public schools. It graduated its first class in 1979, becoming the first elementary through grade twelve arts program in the country.{{sfn|Waldrip|1979|p=133}} The first so-called "survivors", who began in fourth grade, graduated in 1982.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2007|p=2}} SCPA continued to attract national attention, and as a local TV special reported, "educators from all over the country flock[ed] to Cincinnati to see how, and why, it works."{{sfn|Cromwell & North|1982|loc=1:15}} In 1981, SCPA was invited to perform ''[[The Wiz]]'' at the [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|National Theatre]] in [[Washington, DC]], the "Theatre of the Presidents" and oldest major touring house in the country, becoming the first non-professional group to perform there since it opened in 1835.{{cite web| title = A Narrative History of the National Theatre | publisher = The National Theatre Corporation | url = http://www.nationaltheatre.org/location/narrative.htm | accessdate = May 10, 2010}}{{cite news| title = The Baby-Grand 'Wiz' | last = Rosenfeld | first = Megan | newspaper = The Washington Post | date = June 5, 1981 | format = fee required | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost_historical/access/142712182.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS&date=Jun+5%2C+1981&author=By+Megan+Rosenfeld&pub=The+Washington+Post++%281974-Current+file%29&edition=&startpage=D7&desc=The+Baby-Grand+%27Wiz%27 | accessdate = January 24, 2010}} SCPA student [[Rocky Carroll|Roscoe (Rocky) Carroll]] won the 1981 [[National Endowment for the Arts]] Talent Search in drama and became a [[Presidential Scholars Program|Presidential Scholar]] in the Arts. The school received the [[Blue Ribbon Schools Program|Blue Ribbon School]] of the [[United States Department of Education]] in 1984 and the National Secondary School Merit Award in 1985.{{cite news| last = McCarty| first = Mary| title = A Very Public School | newspaper= Cincinnati Magazine| date = April 1986| volume = 19 | number = 7 | page = A14}}{{cite web| title = Blue Ribbon Schools Program | publisher = US Department of Education | page = 65 | url = http://www2.ed.gov/programs/nclbbrs/list-1982.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = January 24, 2010}} By 1985, it had been credited as the model for arts schools in 100 cities in the US, Europe, and Asia, and had been cited in textbooks as a model of excellence in school integration.{{cite journal| title = A Case for Arts Schools | journal = Design for Arts in Education | volume = 87 | last = Galbraith | first = Bruce W | page = 6 |year = 1985 | issn = 0732-0973 | doi=10.1080/07320973.1985.9940730}}{{cite journal | title = Where Magic Happens | journal = The School Musician Director and Teacher | volume = 56 | page = 30 | publisher = Phi Beta Mu | issn = 0036-6676 | year = 1985 | quote = This special place is the model for arts schools in over 100 cities throughout the US, Europe and the Orient}} The school relied heavily on donations, which made up over ten percent of the total budget. The Friends of SCPA (commonly known as The Friends), a nonprofit organization led by parents and members of the business and arts communities, had been a vital source of funding since the school's inception.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=130}} In 1984, The Friends raised over $400,000 to pay the salaries of the artistic director, technical director, costume designer, and dance, strings, and production teachers.{{cite news| last = Koff| first = Steven | title = Guide to Cincinnati and Northern Kentucky Public Schools | newspaper= Cincinnati Magazine|date = August 1984|pages = A7–A8 | volume= 17 | number = 11}} In later years, The Friends raised up to $1 million each year through special events, corporate gifts and sponsorships, advertising sales, and other programs to support the artistic needs of the school including staff salaries, production expenses, scholarships for private lessons, and artists in residence.{{sfn|Vaccariello|Pyle|1993|p=101}} {{Clear}} === Controversy and comeback (1991–2009) === Scandal erupted when founding principal Dickinson resigned in 1991, citing health reasons, while under investigation for alleged improper contact with students off school grounds;{{sfn|Vaccariello|Pyle|1993|p=101}} no charges were ever filed. He was succeeded by Dr. Rosalyn England, former principal of Central VPA High School in St. Louis. Controversy continued and between 1992 and 1995, two teachers confessed to having or attempting to have sex with students and two more were investigated for allegations of sexual misconduct.{{cite news| last = Vaccariello | first = Linda| title =Controversy Follows Principal | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post| date = June 25, 1998 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72817564.html | format = fee required | accessdate = November 27, 2009 }}{{cite news| last = Griggs | first = France | title = The Comeback Kids of SCPA | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post | date = February 17, 2001 | url = http://www.cincypost.com/2001/feb/17/scpa021701.html | accessdate = September 18, 2007 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050110212720/http://www.cincypost.com/2001/feb/17/scpa021701.html | archivedate = January 10, 2005}}{{cite news| last1 = Griggs | first1 = France | last2 = Petrie | first2 = Laurie | title =Show Must Go On for SCPA Students | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post| date = April 20, 1996 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72895276.html | format = fee required | accessdate = December 23, 2009}} In 1992, open conflict with England led to the departure of original Artistic Director Jack Louiso, whom Dickinson had called "the 'life-blood' of the school's artistic endeavors".{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=130}}{{sfn|Vaccariello|Pyle|1993|p=100}} The artistic program would remain in upheaval; four more artistic directors would come and go under England. The controversies took a toll; applications suffered, teachers departed, financial support dwindled and the quality of the productions declined. By 1996, enrollment had fallen from nearly 1,200 to 956.{{cite news| title = Top High Schools Can't Keep Blacks Cincinnati Working To Retain Minorities | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | last = Griggs | first = France | date = April 11, 1994 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72893696.html | format = fee required | accessdate = May 25, 2010}} In April 1996, an arson fire destroyed the school's auditorium, causing over $1 million of damage; it was a turning point for a school then dangerously close to closure. The culprit was never identified. [[Erich Kunzel]], long time [[Maestro]] of the [[Cincinnati Pops Orchestra]] and nationally renowned as "the Prince of [[Pops orchestra|Pops]]",{{cite book |title=Music in Ohio|first=William|last=Osborne|location=Kent, Ohio|publisher=Kent State University Press|isbn=0-87338-775-9|page=225 | year = 2004}} announced his vision for a new SCPA campus near [[Cincinnati Music Hall]], which would be part of an arts and education complex that would help revitalize Over-the-Rhine. A campaign was launched that, over the following 13 years, raised funds and made plans for the new facility.{{cite news| title = Kunzel's Vision Arts Center 'Team Effort' | last = Hutton | first = Mary Ellyn | date = September 5, 1996 |url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72812126.html | format = fee required | accessdate = May 25, 2010 }} England abruptly retired in 1997 and was replaced by Jeff Brokamp, who had been principal of the [[Crest Hills Year-Round School]], which had won awards for its all-year curriculum.{{cite news| title =Crest Hills Principal Selected to Lead SCPA | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post| date = July 10, 2007 }}{{sfn|Vaccariello|1997|p = 79}} Brokamp, with no previous arts experience, began to turn the school around. A new emphasis on academics, more [[Advanced Placement]] courses and more stringent audition standards that admitted only the most dedicated students led to better test scores and a higher level of artistic talent; Brokamp pushed to expand the school's vocational training programs in photography, stage management, and costume design by 50 percent.{{cite news| last1 = Stein | first1 = Jerry| title =New Team Raises Curtain at SCPA | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post| date = September 2, 1997 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67845068.html | format = fee required | accessdate = January 3, 2010}} Applications to audition more than tripled by 2001 and fund-raising rebounded. Brokamp resigned and was replaced by Clarence Crum in 2004, who was followed by John Carlisle in 2006. Carlisle was replaced by Dr. Jonathan Futch, formerly Assistant Principal at [[Withrow High School]]. === Taking the Stage (2009–2010) === {{main article|Taking the Stage}} [[File:Nick Lachey.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Bearded man in brown shirt singing with microphone|Nick Lachey of 98 Degrees, co-creator of ''Taking the Stage'', performs in 2006]] ''[[Taking the Stage]]'', a "musical reality" TV series set at SCPA, premiered on [[MTV]] in March 2009. The series, co-created and co-produced by SCPA graduate [[Nick Lachey]], was a dramatized depiction of life at the school. The show chronicled the lives of five real SCPA high school students and their friends in their careers at SCPA. Each episode featured original music and choreography by the students themselves, performed at the school and other locations in Over-the-Rhine. The first season, which premiered on March 19, 2009, was the number one primetime cable telecast among females 12–24 years old and one of the top four among all viewers 12–34 years old.{{cite web| title =MTV Delivers Two of Cable’s Top 5 Primetime Telecasts Among P12-34: 'Making the Band' and 'Taking the Stage' | work = TV by the Numbers| url = http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/04/03/mtv-delivers-two-of-cables-top-5-primetime-telecasts-among-p12-34-making-the-band-and-taking-the-stage/15911 | accessdate = January 6, 2010}} The second season began filming at the school in 2009, and first aired on January 16, 2010.{{cite web| title = Taking the Stage – Season Two | work = MTV.com | url = http://www.mtv.com/shows/taking_the_stage/season_2/series.jhtml | accessdate = January 6, 2010}} The show was cut from one hour to 30 minutes and focused on new transfer students instead of current SCPA students, leading some students and parents to complain that the admission process had been compromised. The school denied the claim. It ran for 16 episodes, through April 15, 2010. In May 2010, MTV announced there would be no third season.{{cite news|title=MTV Cancels Taking The Stage|first=John|last=Kiesewetter|work=Cincinnati.com|publisher= Gannett Company | date = May 10, 2010 | accessdate = May 7, 2010|url=http://cincinnati.com/blogs/tv/2010/05/05/mtv-cancels-taking-the-stage/}} The school was paid $10,000 for each of the nine episodes in season one and twelve in season two.{{cite news| last = Fisher| first = Ben | title =SCPA Debuts Tonight | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer| date = March 19, 2009 | url = http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20090319/NEWS0102/903190306 | accessdate = January 6, 2010}} The show attracted international attention for the school and interest from prospective students around the world; applications for admission increased by 60 percent in 2009.{{cite news| title = SCPA Likes Its MTV | last = Kieswetter | first = John | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = January 24, 2010 | url = http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20100123/ENT11/1240323/SCPA-likes-its-MTV | accessdate = January 27, 2010}} {{Clear}} === Washington Park (2010– ) === [[File:Cincinnati-SCPA.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Four story brick and steel building before blue sky and clouds with trees and grass in foreground | The Erich Kunzel Center for Arts and Education, the new home of SCPA, under construction in 2009. The contemporary design is meant to blend with the historic context of Over-the-Rhine.]] In the aftermath of the 1996 fire, a group of local benefactors led by Kunzel formed the [[Greater Cincinnati Arts and Education Center]] (GCAEC) to, in Kunzel's words, "transform the area around [[Washington Park (Cincinnati, Ohio)|Washington Park]] into a unique arts community that would include a new School for the Creative and Performing Arts."{{cite news| title = Plans Sees Art World in Washington Park | last = Clark | first = Michael D | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67846094.html | format = fee required | accessdate = June 7, 2010}} The GCAEC committed $31 million, the Cincinnati Public Schools $34 million, and the State of Ohio $7 million, to combine SCPA with the Schiel Primary School for Arts Enrichment in one building to create the first public kindergarten through twelfth grade arts school in what the GCAEC called the "nationally unprecedented public school system – private sector partnership".{{cite news| last = Hutton | first = Mary Ellyn | title =Dignitaries Hail New SCPA at Ceremony| newspaper= The Cincinnati Post| date = September 7, 2007 | url =http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-168527896.html | format = fessdate = December 20, 2009}} Schiel, built in 1911 as an elementary school for the [[Corryville]] neighborhood, was converted to a Spanish-language magnet school in 1974 and again to an arts enrichment school in 1985.For Schiel founding, see {{cite book | page = 138 | title = An Expression of the Community: Cincinnati Public Schools' Legacy of Art and Architecture | last1 = Ellis | first1 = Anita J | last2 = Langsam | first2= Walter E | last3 = Flischel | first3 = Robert A | publisher = Art League Press | location = Cincinnati, OH | edition = 1st | oclc = 298021351 | year = 2001}}. Formerly aligned with the [[Cincinnati Art Museum]], it became an independent college of design in 1998.{{cite news| title = A Long-Awaited Move | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | date = June 3, 2004 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-117673055.html | format = fee required | accessdate = June 7, 2010}} The [[Ensemble Theatre of Cincinnati]] and Know Theater are also part of the rich cultural community that has developed around the park and Music Hall.{{cite news| last = Fischer | first = Ben| title =The Arts Incubator | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer| date = September 3, 2007}} The combined school retains the name School for the Creative and Performing Arts.{{cite news|title=SCPA Building Named for Kunzel |work=WLWT.com |date=December 7, 2009 |url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/21892804/detail.html |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310060549/http://www.wlwt.com/news/21892804/detail.html |archivedate=March 10, 2012 }} Private donors will have a significant and ongoing voice in how the school is operated. According to the ''Cincinnati Enquirer'', the school board approved a plan in 2003 to allow the GCAEC to choose five of the twelve members of the Local School Decision-Making Committee (LSDMC), an independent body that provides oversight for the school, as a condition for continued fund-raising.{{cite news| last = Mrozowski| first = Jennifer| title = Donors to Have Say in Arts School | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = May 20, 2003 | url =http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2003/05/20/loc_cps20.html | accessdate = November 27, 2009}} This private sector oversight has been criticized by union leaders as excluding faculty and staff.{{cite news| title = Union Fights Change at SCPA | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | date = June 6, 2003 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-102910838.html | accessdate = June 7, 2010 | format = fee required}} The GCAEC began fundraising for an endowment in 2010, and as of 2010, had pledged to contribute at least $150,000 per year to the school. No plans were announced for the Old Woodward building, but it was expected to remain vacant for years. An Ohio School Facilities Assessment in 2002 reported that it was "very attractive architecturally and merits any means required to preserve it", and that residential units would be the best use, but that a major redevelopment project, while attractive to private developers, would be prohibitively expensive. The area surrounding the old building has seen a resurgence in recent years including a public green space named Cutter Playground directly north of the building, currently home to the OTR Urban Kickball League.{{cite web | last = Dohoney | first = Milton, Jr. | date = June 2, 2011 | title = Conveyance Request for SCPA Greenspace | publisher = City of Cincinnati | id = 201001335 | url = http://city-egov.cincinnati-oh.gov/Webtop/ws/council/public/child/Blob/32931.pdf | accessdate = August 13, 2012 }}{{cite web | last = Kessler | first = Jenny | url = http://www.urbancincy.com/2011/05/over-the-rhine-urban-kickball-league-gears-up-for-second-season/ | title = OTR Urban Kickball League gears up for second season | publisher = UrbanCincy | date = May 5, 2011 | accessdate = August 13, 2012 }} In November, 2012, the building was sold at auction to Core Redevelopment of [[Indianapolis]] for $1.3 million. It had been appraised at $8.5 million. The developer's plans for the building were not made clear at the time.{{cite web | last = London | first = John| url = http://www.wlwt.com/news/local-news/cincinnati/Indianapolis-developer-to-buy-former-SCPA-building/-/13549970/17376278/-/u9xi0k/-/index.html| title = Indianapolis developer to buy former SCPA building | publisher = WLWT Cincinnati | date = November 12, 2012 | accessdate = November 12, 2012 }} == Admission == The school has been criticized as "elitist" for its selective admission policies.{{sfn|Cromwell & North|1982|loc=9:02 "It's not easy to get into this school. Everyone has to audition. So far this year, some 1,500 students have auditioned for the 200 spots opening up in the fall. Making youngsters audition has led some to charge that SCPA is elitist."}} Prospective students are evaluated on their artistic sensitivity and potential.{{sfn|Cromwell & North|1982|loc=10:15}} Students entering grades four through six are required to audition in every arts major; older students may audition in only the areas they choose.{{cite web|url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/faq.html |title=FAQ |publisher=The School for Creative and Performing Arts |accessdate=November 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310084822/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/faq.html |archivedate=March 10, 2009 }} Each applicant performs in front of up to seven teachers in different areas in the day-long process, which is designed to ensure that no student is admitted to a program in which they do not belong.{{sfn|Cromwell & North| 1982|loc=9:12 "The reason, obviously, is so that some student does not come here and get hurt. There is nothing worse than being some place you don't belong."}} Admission is granted to students scoring 8 out of 10 points in at least one area.{{sfn|Cromwell & North| 1982|loc=10:15}} On average, 1,700 students apply each year, 1,000 are invited to audition, and 250 are accepted.{{cite news| title = Hope, Jitters Mix at SCPA Tryouts | last = Moores | first = Lew | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = February 18, 2001 | url = http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/02/18/loc_hope_jitters_mix_at.html | accessdate = January 27, 2010}} Attendance is free for Cincinnati Public School students. Ten percent of students come from outside the district—some from outside the state—and pay tuition to attend. Tuition for the 2006–2007 year was $6,309 for out-of-district students and $9,654 for out-of-state students. As a magnet school founded to promote school integration, racial and economic diversity have been important factors in admissions decisions. The student body was 52.1 percent black, 41.7 percent low income, and 7.7 percent disabled in 2009–10.{{cite web|url=http://www.ode.state.oh.us/reportcardfiles/2009-2010/BUILD/068619.pdf |title=School for Creative and Performing Arts High School |publisher=Ohio Department of Education |page=5 |format=PDF |year=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610093944/http://www.ode.state.oh.us/reportcardfiles/2009-2010/BUILD/068619.PDF |archivedate=June 10, 2011 }} In 2007, in response to a US Supreme Court decision prohibiting racial criteria for assigning students to public schools, CPS eliminated race and gender as determining factors in magnet school admissions.{{cite court | litigants =Parents Involved in Community Schools v. Seattle School Dist. No. 1 | vol = 551 | reporter = U.S.| opinion = 71 | court = Supreme Court | year = 2007 | url = http://www.brennancenter.org/page/-/d/download_file_49773.pdf | format = PDF }}{{cite news| last = Fischer| first = Ben| title = City's Magnet School Rules Have Changed | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = December 27, 2007 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/enquirer/access/1717082951.html?FMT=FT&dids=1717082951:1717082951&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+27%2C+2007&author=Ben+Fischer&pub=Cincinnati+Enquirer&desc=City%27s+magnet+school+rules+have+changed | format = fee required | accessdate = December 22, 2009}} School officials insist this will have little impact, despite parent concerns that the decision will erode diversity. == Curriculum == === Arts === [[File:Wiz in DC SCPA Cincinnati 1981.jpg|upright|thumb|alt=Young man in lion costume kneels in front of young girl with pigtails, both singing|SCPA performance of ''The Wiz'' at the National Theatre in Washington, D.C. in 1981]] [[File:King and I SCPA Cincinnati 1982.jpg|thumb|upright|SCPA student performs "The Small House of Uncle Thomas" in ''[[The King and I]]'' in 1982]] [[File:Schiel Suzuki Strings with Cincinnati Pops.jpg|thumb|alt=five children dressed in black and white play violins standing in front of seated adults in orange jackets|[[Suzuki method|Suzuki]] strings students from the Schiel school perform with the Cincinnati Pops at the opening of the new building in 2010]] The curriculum is designed to prepare students for professional careers in the arts. Each student concentrates in at least one major area: creative writing, dance, drama, music, [[technical theater|stagecraft]], and visual art. Younger students often concentrate in two or more. High school students are required to specialize and major only in the areas in which they have potential to do professional work.{{cite web|url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/factsheet.html |title=Fact Sheet |publisher=The School for Creative and Performing Arts |accessdate=November 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414062003/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/factsheet.html |archivedate=April 14, 2009 }} Advanced students study up to two hours each day in their major. Forty percent of the students stay at least two hours after school for rehearsals, private lessons, and productions. The program stresses discipline and performance. There are no appreciation courses; the curriculum emphasizes that arts appreciation grows from practicing an art.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=128}} The interrelation of the arts is also stressed. All students take at least one course in each major area. A dancer, for example, will be required to study visual art, drama, and music.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=129}} The visual arts program includes drawing, painting, photography, sculpting, digital art, and art history. The program is highly structured, emphasizing technique and control over free expression, which has attracted criticism from the local art community.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=129}} Art students receive individualized instruction, participate in art exhibits and competitions, undertake commissioned work, and work at in-house galleries and off-site exhibits. Most art majors take Advanced Placement art courses by the end of their sophomore year, and many attend pre-college programs at major universities between their high school years.{{cite web|title=Visual Arts – More Than Meets the Eye |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/visual-art.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505061520/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/visual-art.html |archivedate=May 5, 2010 }} The drama program stresses technique and performance; students must perform in public at least twice a year.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=129}} There are three major dramatic productions each season, and high school students are required to compete in the [[English Speaking Union]] Shakespeare Contest. Advanced students audition for the Acting Ensemble Company, which provides a full season of performances in venues outside the school.{{cite web|title=Drama Department- Acting Upon Success |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/drama.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100501145320/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/drama.html |archivedate=May 1, 2010 }} The creative writing program focuses on writing as an art in journalism, script writing, poetry, and creative non-fiction.{{cite journal| title = Curriculum and the Performing Arts: Created by Staff, Inspired by the Muse | last = Fowler | first = Joy | journal = The English Journal | publisher = National Council of Teachers of English | volume = 94 | issue = 6 |date = July 2005| page = 49 | issn = 0013-8274 | doi=10.2307/30046503| jstor = 30046503 }} Students participate in writing competitions, internships, and develop portfolios to showcase their work.{{cite web|title=Creative Writing – Uncapping the Power of the Pen |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/creative-writing.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422041344/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/creative-writing.html |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }} The dance program was founded on the training principles of the "most famous dance schools of Europe",{{sfn|Cromwell & North | 1982|loc=4:21}} which emphasize body training. All dancers are required to study ballet, but may also learn modern dance, jazz, tap, and other forms of dance.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=129}} There are nine levels of ballet, and students begin intensive training in fourth grade. Dance classes meet for at least two 45-minute periods every day; advanced students may train for three or more. Dance Ensemble, selected by audition, stages public performances throughout the year.{{cite web|title=Dance Department – First Steps to Professional Success |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/dance.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100501152216/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/dance.html |archivedate=May 1, 2010 }} The instrumental music program offers specializations in orchestra, band, piano, jazz, percussion, and harp. Students major in an instrument and specialized training begins in grade four. Advanced students take private lessons, arranged by the school, and have master classes with guest instructors from the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.{{cite web|title=Instrumental Music Department – Noteworthy Training for Professional Musical Success |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/Music-Instrumental/overview.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422051725/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/Music-Instrumental/overview.html |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }} Vocal music students audition to perform in one of 13 vocal performance groups. High school students may audition for the most selective of these, "13th & Broadway", which performs throughout the region.{{cite web|title=Vocal Department – Where Success Takes Voice |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/vocal.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325055440/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/vocal.html |archivedate=March 25, 2009 }} The technical theater program offers college-level training in [[stage management]], [[Lighting designer|lighting]], [[Sound design|sound]], and [[Scenic design|set]] and [[costume design]]. Each specialty has a lab for students to develop concepts and practice technique, and students work side-by-side with professional trades people in their chosen field.{{cite web|title=Technical Theater – Building Strong Futures |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/technicaltheater.html |accessdate=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422051731/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/arts/technicaltheater.html |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }} Student present to the faculty of their major department twice a year in a "proficiency review" to assess their progress. It is a learning experience for younger students, but students in grades 7–12 who fail to attain a passing rating are placed on probation and must pass their subsequent review to be allowed to continue in that major. Students must audition if they wish to change majors for the following year.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2007|pp=21,25}} The highlight of the performance season is a major musical production which is an important source of revenue for the school.{{cite web| title = 2009–2010 SCPA Box Office Season | publisher = School for Creative and Performing Arts | url = http://scpa.cps-k12.org/boxoffice/documents/09-10season.pdf|format = PDF| accessdate = January 24, 2010}}{{dead link|date=July 2013}} There are two ballets each year: ''[[The Nutcracker]]'' in the winter and a piece from repertoire in the spring. The technical and production aspects of performances are handled entirely by students, a level of responsibility the school claims is unusual even among arts schools.{{cite news| last = Stein | first = Jerry | title =SCPA Names Artistic Director | newspaper= The Cincinnati Post | date = January 23, 2006 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-141216967.html | format = fee required | accessdate = December 22, 2009 | quote = I believe we are the only arts high school program where the students do lighting, sound, scenery and costuming. That is something that is really important because it not only allows our students to perform in all the productions but to work behind the scenes.}} Strict racial balance is maintained in all school performances through "non-traditional casting", in which the race of each lead role alternates in each production.{{sfn|Borman|Spring|1984|p=126}} SCPA students and faculty have performed with professional companies and in major venues including [[Carnegie Hall]] and the [[Kennedy Center]].{{cite news| last = Sonnenberg| first = Elissa| title = Raising Voices | newspaper = Cincinnati Magazine|date = September 2008| url = http://www.cincinnatimagazine.com/article.aspx?id=61634 | accessdate = January 15, 2010}}{{cite news| last = Fischer | first = Ben | title = SCPA's Chamber Orchestra Invited Back to Carnegie Hall | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer| date = April 11, 2008 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/enquirer/access/1710693851.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+11%2C+2008&author=Ben+Fischer&pub=Cincinnati+Enquirer&desc=SCPA%27s+chamber+orchestra+invited+back+to+Carnegie+Hall&pqatl=google | format = fee required | accessdate = January 15, 2010}} Students are selected to perform with every major local arts company, including the Cincinnati Opera, [[Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park]], and the [[Cincinnati Ballet]], and appear in local television programs and commercials. SCPA students have performed on [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] with the Cincinnati Pops and toured with Broadway productions including ''[[42nd Street (musical)|42nd Street]]'' and ''[[The King and I]]''.{{cite news| title =SCPA Spotlighted in 'Pops Holiday' | last = Hutton | first = Mary Ellen | date = December 12, 1996 | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72861214.html | format = fee required | accessdate = January 15, 2010}} Students on tour continue their studies at "set school" and rejoin their classmates when they return.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2007|p=4}} SCPA students are encouraged to compete in arts competitions at all levels, including international contests like the [[World Piano Competition]] and the [[American High School Theater Festival]] in [[Edinburgh]].{{sfn|Student Handbook|2007|p=4}} Honors since 2008 have included first place in the Ohioana Robert Fox Award for Young Writers, a bronze medal at the Cincinnati World Piano Competition, top honors at the Days of International Choir Music Competition, and the 2008 Cincinnati Arts Association Overture Award in Visual Art.{{cite web|title=2009 Robert Fox Winners |publisher=Ohioana Library Association |url=http://www.ohioana.org/awards/foxlist.pdf |format=PDF |page=2 |accessdate=January 15, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902114420/http://www.ohioana.org/awards/foxlist.pdf |archivedate=September 2, 2009 }} === Academics === Students are required to complete a standard CPS academic curriculum alongside their arts studies and the school day is 45 minutes longer than other Cincinnati public schools. SCPA ranks first in the district on standardized test scores at the elementary school level. At the high school level, only [[Walnut Hills High School]], Cincinnati's selective public college preparatory magnet, ranks higher.{{cite book | title = Partnering Dance And Education: Intelligent Moves For Changing Times | page = 39 | last = Hanna | first = Judith Lynne | location = Champaign, IL | publisher = Human Kinetics | year = 1999 | isbn = 0-88011-511-4 }} In 2009, the graduation rate was 95.5 percent and the mean score on the [[ACT (test)|ACT]], a standardized college admissions test, was 23 (at the 69th [[percentile]]).{{cite web|title=School for Creative and Perf Arts High School |publisher=Ohio Department of Education |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/DownloadCenter/State_Report_Card/SCPAreport.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=September 22, 2010 |page=6 |year=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070729044318/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/DownloadCenter/State_Report_Card/SCPAreport.pdf |archivedate=July 29, 2007 }}{{cite web| title = ACT High School Profile Report | publisher = ACT | url = http://www.act.org/news/data/07/pdf/National2007.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = February 23, 2010 | page = 10}} On the Ohio Department of Education 2009–2010 School Year Report card, SCPA was designated "Effective" and Schiel was designated "Excellent."{{cite web | title = Schiel Prim Schl Arts Enrchmnt Elementary School | publisher = Ohio Department of Education | url = http://www.ode.state.oh.us/reportcardfiles/2009-2010/BUILD/033712.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = September 22, 2010 | year = 2010}} Ninety percent of graduating seniors continue on to college, and those students receive one of the highest levels of scholarship funding in the city. In 2007, the 98 graduating seniors received a combined $7.1 million in scholarships and SCPA averaged $72,449 per student, the third most of any public or private school in Cincinnati.{{cite press release | title = Cincinnati Public Schools is Proud to Highlight District's Achievements and Community Support | publisher = Cincinnati Public Schools | date = May 30, 2007| url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1281802811.html | format = fee required | accessdate = January 3, 2010}} == Extracurricular activities == SCPA offers a limited range of sports and other activities compared to other CPS schools, as students are expected to commit significant after-school time to practice and performance. Volunteer community service opportunities are organized by the Positive School Culture committee and made available to students in every grade. Student Council is elected from each grade and raises funds for student activities. [[National Honor Society]] (for grades ten to twelve) and [[National Junior Honor Society]] (for grades seven through nine) are by invitation only to students who demonstrate outstanding achievement, service, leadership, and citizenship.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2009|pp=28–29}} German, French, and Spanish clubs are open to all students and plan language-related activities. The Astronomy Club for Girls for fourth through sixth graders takes advantage of the nearby [[Cincinnati Observatory]] to explore astronomy. The Brain Bowl team, also for fourth through sixth graders, participates in academic competitions. Students Involved in Fostering Tolerance (SIFT) works to promote tolerance and diversity through awareness field trips and fundraisers.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2009|pp=28–29}} Student publications include the [[yearbook]], ''1310 Address of the Arts,'' a monthly newspaper published by the Creative Writing department, but open to contributions by all students, and ''Pandora's Backpages,'' a full-color magazine featuring creative writing, visual art and musical compositions by students, faculty, and alumni.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2009|pp=28–29}}{{cite web|title=In the Spotlight |url=http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/award/inthespotlight.html |publisher=School for Creative and Performing Arts |accessdate=November 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201042228/http://scpa.cps-k12.org/about/award/inthespotlight.html |archivedate=February 1, 2009 }} The school competes athletically in Cincinnati's Independent conference in boys' and girls' basketball, boys' baseball, and girls' softball.{{sfn|Student Handbook|2009|pp=28–29}} Intramural sports are open to all high school students. == Campus == [[File:SCPA Corbett Theater.jpg|thumb|alt=Theater with blue seats and wood paneled walls | The Corbett Theater, called the "jewel of the project" by lead architect Curtis Moody. It is named for Cincinnati's most important benefactors of the arts, J. Ralph and Patricia Corbett, whose $2.6 million lead donation was instrumental in building the new school.{{cite news| title = Corbett Pledges $2.6 Million to School | last = Griggs | first = France | date = August 1, 2000 | newspaper = The Cincinnati Post | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-64907397.html | format = fee required | accessdate = June 7, 2010}}]] The new building, called the Erich Kunzel Center for Arts and Education, opened for 1,350 students in August, 2010.{{cite news| title = It's a Wrap:Doors Close on School for Creative and Performing Arts' Long Run | last = Fischer| first = Ben | date = May 26, 2010| newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/enquirer/access/2043194861.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+27%2C+2010&author=Ben%20Fischer&pub=Cincinnati+Enquirer&desc=It%27s+a+wrap%3A+Doors+close+on+School+for+Creative+and+Performing+Arts%27+long+run&pqatl=google| accessdate = September 22, 2010}} The $72 million facility, bordered by Elm, Race, and 12th streets and facing Central Parkway, was designed by Moody–Nolan, a large minority-owned architectural firm known for its numerous design awards, and is the largest development project in Over-the-Rhine since Music Hall.{{cite web| title = Curtis J. Moody, FAIA | publisher = AIA Columbus | url = http://www.aiacolumbus.org/component/content/article/40-fellows/131-curtis-j-moody-faia | accessdate = June 8, 2010}} Civic leaders have called construction of the school "key to renovation of Over-the-Rhine" and development plans for the area include the renovation of Music Hall, a new parking garage and public plaza nearby, and a major expansion of Washington Park.{{cite news| title = Performing Arts School Making History in OTR | last = Leach | first = Tanya Bricking | newspaper = Business Courier of Cincinnati | date = April 25, 2008 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/2008/04/28/focus3.html | accessdate = June 10, 2010}} A reflective stainless steel panel with a [[diapering]] pattern curves around the L-shaped building and an "urban curve" of zinc wraps the main theater at the front of the building, contrasting with the brick walls of the school, the design and materials of which reflect those used in the building's neighborhood. The box office is a red, [[smokestack]]-shaped structure that projects a beam of light up into the sky. The four-story, [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|disabled accessible]] building of {{convert|250000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} combines arts and academic spaces on each floor, arranged by grade, with the youngest students on the lowest floor.{{cite news| title = School Designed to Showcase Creativity | last = Gelfand | first = Janelle | newspaper = The Cincinnati Enquirer | date = April 30, 2006}} The main entrance features student sculptures selected by contest. An "Avenue of the Arts", with gallery space for more student artwork, links the 750-seat main Corbett Theater, the 350-seat Mayerson Theater, and a 120-seat [[black box theater]]. The Corbett Theater has an {{convert|80|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} stage, a hydraulically operated [[orchestra pit]], and is acoustically isolated from the rest of the building.{{cite news| last = Gelfand| first = Janelle | title =Designed with the Arts in Mind | newspaper= The Cincinnati Enquirer| date = April 30, 2006 }} An outdoor amphitheater is also planned. The music facilities include rooms for band, orchestra, jazz ensemble, and vocal music, along with a music library, a grand piano studio, and twelve soundproof practice rooms. Other arts-specific spaces include specialized drama rooms, four rooms for painting and sculpture, and a photography studio with adjoining darkroom. The [[stagecraft|technical theater]] facilities include labs for lighting and sound engineering, as well as costume, scenery, and stage prop shops. The main {{convert|5500|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} gymnasium is augmented by a fitness center and six multipurpose spaces for gym and dance. Academic facilities include four project labs, two chemistry rooms, two biology rooms, and a {{convert|4300|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} library, with 45 academic classrooms designed around flexible "extended learning areas" where students from different classes can study in groups. == People == [[File:Sarah Jessica Parker 2 Shankbone 2009 Tribeca.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Sarah Jessica Parker in black dress and flashy diamond necklace | ''Sex and the City'' star Sarah Jessica Parker in 2009]] {{mainlist|List of School for Creative and Performing Arts people}} SCPA has produced notable graduates in a wide range of artistic fields.{{cite journal| title = Cincinnati USA City Guide 2007 | publisher = ''Cincinnati Magazine'' | year = 2007 | page = 88 }} Alumni include [[Cyrus Vorhis]], producer of ''[[Bulletproof Monk]], [[Kung Fu Panda]], [[Robin Hood (2010 film)|Robin Hood]]'' and the [[Emmy]]-nominated miniseries ''[[Sleeper Cell (TV miniseries)|Sleeper Cell]]'' and [[Todd Louiso]], director of ''[[Love Liza]]'' and actor in ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]],'' ''[[High Fidelity (film)|High Fidelity]]'' and other films.
